abstract: High-resolution 2D and 3D electron microscopy have been employed to investigate the dealloying of S phase (Al2CuMg) particles in an AA 2024-T3 aluminium alloy. Preferential dissolution of magnesium and aluminium produced a sponge-like remnant with nanosize porosity and a copper-rich remnant network. The dealloyed S phase remnant retains a tetragonal structure with a smaller lattice parameter than the S phase. Metallic copper nanoparticles, constituting 4-8% of the dealloyed remnant, are present at the intersections of remnant branches. At the surface of the remnant, a copper layer of ~2nm thickness is formed, which terminates further dissolution of the less noble elements.

author_highlights.sentence: The main body of the dealloyed S phase remnant has the same crystal structure as S phase.
Copper nanoparticles are present at the intersections of remnant branches.
At the surface of the remnant, a copper layer of ∼2 nm thick is present.
The volume fraction of the dealloyed S phase remnant is 45–60%.

body_text.sentence: In the present study, dealloying of S phase in AA 2024-T3 alloy has been imaged in two dimensions (2D) and three dimensions (3D) by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to provide new insights into the morphological, compositional and crystallographic changes during the dealloying process, especially the behaviour of copper atoms.
body_text.title: Introduction
